# üéØ What is a web API?

::: notes
-   (10?) minutes into my talk, and I'm finally talking about the thing in the title.
:::

## üìò APIs are: {transition="slide-in none-out"}

ü§ñ‚ÜîÔ∏èü§ñ Services that enable communication between computer programs.

::: notes
-   "Application programming interface." (but almost always API)
-   (slide)
-   You might hear the arguments to a function referred to as the "API" of that function.
:::

## üìò Web APIs are: {transition="none-in slide-out"}

ü§ñ‚ÜîÔ∏èü§ñ Services that enable communication between computer programs *on the internet.*

::: notes
-   *Technically* you don't have to be on the internet to use some Web APIs
-   You can run something locally
    -   plumber API running in RStudio session
    -   {plumber} = *creating* APIs
    -   I won't cover in this talk
-   Even locally, behaves in the style of the internet.
-   Still a web API.
:::

## üìÜ You use web APIs every day!

::: incremental
-   "Login with ![](images/Google__G__Logo.svg){height="30"} \| ![](images/Apple_logo_white.svg){height="30" style="text-align: top;"}"
-   "Create ![](images/Zoom_logo_2022.svg){height="20"} meeting" in work messenger
-   "üìÖ Add to Calendar"
-   *Technically: Load any web page == `GET`*
:::

::: notes
-   (don't comment on logo alignment)
-   Zoom: Or similar app integrations.
-   Button on a web page, goes to Google or Apple calendar, etc.
-   For "technically":
    -   When you fetch a web page, you're using the GET method to ask the server to send you the page.
    -   There are 5 main methods for web apis.
        -   GET, POST = create something new usually, PUT = replace, PATCH = edit, DELETE; often just GET and/or POST
    -   Today we'll mostly talk about GET.
:::

# ![The logo for the R programming language. A blue Lettter R on top of a gray oval.](images/R_logo.svg){style="float: right;" width="400"} What are some ways you can interact with APIs from R?

::: notes
-   Again, you're already doing some of these.
:::

## üöú Scrape web pages with rvest {transition="slide-in none-out"}

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](images/rvest.svg){fig-alt="The rvest package logo." fig-align="left" width="400"}
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
::: incremental
-   Load page into R.
-   Pull parts out into lists, data.frames, etc.
    -   See [SelectorGadget](https://rvest.tidyverse.org/articles/selectorgadget.html) article
-   Check `<target.domain>/robots.txt`
:::
:::
:::

::: notes
-   rvest = harvest
-   We'll see a detailed example shortly.
-   (see slide)
-   robots.txt
    -   Rules for that site.
    -   Often includes site map to make scraping easier.
:::

## üöú Scrape web pages with rvest {transition="none-in slide-out"}

## üí™üèæ Interact with APIs via httr2

::: fragment
`{httr}` also exists, `{httr2}` is easier to use
:::

::: fragment
```{r httr2}
#| eval: false
#| code-line-numbers: "|2-3|4-9|10-11|12-14|15|16"
library(httr2)
my_cool_result <- request("example.com") |> 
  # https://example.com
  req_url_path_append("a") |>
  # https://example.com/a
  req_url_path_append("b") |>
  # https://example.com/a/b
  req_url_path_append("search.html") |>
  # https://example.com/a/b/search.html
  req_url_query(q = "the cool ice") |> 
  # https://example.com/a/b/search.html?q=the%20cool%20ice
  req_oauth_client_credentials(
    oauth_client("example", "https://example.com/get_token")
  ) |> 
  req_perform() |> 
  resp_body_json()
```
:::

::: notes
-   No logo yet, unfortunately.
-   Hadley Wickham wrote both
    -   httr2 includes things he wishes he had done.
    -   More pipe-friendly
-   Build requests to the API one piece at a time.
-   Helpers like url_path_append
-   Query = the part of the URL after the question mark.
-   OAUTH(2) = main authentication standard on the web
-   Complicated
-   Won't go into details today
-   Great that httr2 mostly takes care of it for you!
-   Detailed example later.
-   PAUSE FOR QUESTIONS SO FAR
:::

# [![The National UFO Reporting Center home page, featuring a person looking up at a light in the sky.](images/nuforc.png){style="float: right;" width="400"}](https://nuforc.org/) Case Study: Fetching and enriching a TidyTuesday dataset

## üîç Find a dataset {transition="slide-in none-out"}

üì¶ {ttmeta}

```{r ttmeta-intro}
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
library(kableExtra)
ttmeta::tt_summary_tbl |> 
  head() |> 
  dplyr::select(year, week, date, title) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    `(urls)` = "..."
  )
```

::: notes
-   ttmeta uses tidytuesdayR and the GIT API to summarize TT datasets.
:::

## üîç Find a dataset {transition="none-in none-out"}

üì¶ {ttmeta}

```{r ttmeta-datasets}
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
ttmeta::tt_datasets_metadata |> 
  head() |> 
  dplyr::select(year, week, dataset_name) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    `(more properties)` = "..."
  )
```

::: notes
-   For each dataset we have number of variables, number of observations, and then details about the variables: name, class, n_unique, min, max, description.
-   Shiny app and/or API coming soon!
:::

## üîç Find a dataset {transition="none-in none-out"}

```{r ttmeta-potential}
#| eval: true
#| code-line-numbers: "1|4-15"
potential_datasets <- ttmeta::tt_datasets_metadata |>
  dplyr::filter(lengths(variable_details) > 0) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    has_latitude = purrr::map_lgl(
      variable_details,
      ~ any(stringr::str_detect(.x$variable, "latitude"))
    ),
    has_longitude = purrr::map_lgl(
      variable_details,
      ~ any(stringr::str_detect(.x$variable, "longitude"))
    ),
    has_time = purrr::map_lgl(
      variable_details,
      ~ any(stringr::str_detect(.x$variable, "time"))
    )
  ) |> 
  dplyr::filter(has_latitude, has_longitude, has_time) |> 
  dplyr::left_join(ttmeta::tt_summary_tbl, by = c("year", "week")) |> 
  dplyr::select(year, date, dataset_name) |>
  dplyr::mutate(url = glue::glue("https://tidytues.day/{year}/{date}"))
```

::: notes
-   Start with tt_datasets_metadata
-   Find latitude, longitude, and time.

## üöú (Re) Scrape the data {transition="slide-in none-out"}

![](images/nuforc_table.png)

::: notes
-   Time information wasn't clear.
-   Original site had new data available.

## üöú (Re) Scrape the data {transition="none-in slide-out"}

```{r ufo-scrape}
#| code-line-numbers: "1|2|4-7|9|11-24|19-21|22|26"
url_report_index <- "https://nuforc.org/webreports/ndxshape.html"
html_report_index <- rvest::read_html(url_report_index)

url_reports_all <- html_report_index |>
  rvest::html_elements("td a") |> # From SelectorGadget
  rvest::html_attr("href") |>
  rvest::url_absolute(url_report_index)

report_dir <- here::here("data", "ufos")

url_reports_all |>
  purrr::walk(
    \(url_report) {
      report_name <- paste0(
        stringr::str_extract(url_report, "[^/.]+(?=\\.html$)"),
        ".rds"
      )

      rvest::read_html(url_report) |>
        rvest::html_element("table") |>
        rvest::html_table(na.strings = c("NA", "")) |>
        saveRDS(fs::path(report_dir, report_name))
    }
  )

data_ufo_reports <- fs::dir_map(report_dir, readRDS)
```

::: notes
-   Get all of the links to separate reports.
-   Scraping can be slow, save as you go.
-   Tell it to treat both "NA" and blank as NA.
-   {fs} has a convenience function to do something to every file in a dir.
:::

```{r ss-tests}
#| eval: true

response <- httr2::request("https://api.sunrise-sunset.org/json") |>
```

```{r ss-tests2}
#| eval: true

response$results
```

## üî¨ Sunrise-Sunset API: Tests {transition="none-in none-out"}

```{r ss-tests3}
fetch_day_parts <- function(latitude, longitude, date) {
  # Grab the actual date, in case it's a datetime.
  date <- lubridate::date(date)
  
  # Do the call.
  response <- httr2::request("https://api.sunrise-sunset.org/json") |> 
    httr2::req_url_query(
      lat = latitude,
      lng = longitude,
      date = date,
      formatted = 0
    ) |> 
    httr2::req_user_agent("api demo for Ghana R Users Community") |>
    httr2::req_perform()
  
  result <- response |> 
    httr2::resp_body_json()
  
  if (result$status == "OK") {
    return(result$results)
  }
  cli::cli_abort(result$status)
}
```

## üî¨ Sunrise-Sunset API: Tests {transition="none-in slide-out"}

Other tests

-   Time for 10 calls, 100 calls
-   Variation for rounded lat, long, date
-   Try to be kind!

::: notes
-   Difference was small all the way to the tens place for latitude and longitude.
-   Ended up rounding all of my data to tens place and date to the week for good enough resolution.
:::

## üïõ Sunrise-Sunset API: Hit the API {transition="slide-in none-out"}

```{r hit-api}
day_parts_map_raw <- distinct_rounded_place_dates |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    day_parts = purrr::pmap(
      list(latitude, longitude, rounded_date),
      fetch_day_parts,
      .progress = TRUE
    )
  )

saveRDS(day_parts_map_raw, here::here("data", "data_day_parts_map_raw.rds"))
```

::: notes
-   Only hit the API once per distinct thing.
-   Purr is beautiful for this sort of thing.
-   Progress was helpful (advance)
:::
